So the first thing I wanna say about Battlefield 1 is that this game is straight up the peak of the entire Battlefield series. No joke, no debate ‚Äî this is THE ONE.
BF1 hits different. It‚Äôs the kind of game where you tell yourself ‚Äúone quick match‚Äù and suddenly it‚Äôs 3 AM and you‚Äôre screaming ‚ÄúFOR THE EMPIRE‚Äù while charging with a bayonet like a psychopath.

The graphics?
Bro‚Ä¶ even in 2025 this game looks cleaner, grittier and way more atmospheric than half the shooters released today. There‚Äôs something about the dust, the smoke, the lighting, the explosions ‚Äî everything feels handcrafted.
This isn‚Äôt graphics, this is cinema. Every match looks like a war documentary shot with a Hollywood budget.

The sound design?
Don‚Äôt even get me started.
Mortars, artillery, the screams, the guns ‚Äî it all hits your soul.
You don‚Äôt play BF1, you experience it.
Half the time I‚Äôm running through the trenches hearing bullets fly past and I swear I can feel my chair vibrating.

The gameplay?
THIS is Battlefield. Massive chaos, huge maps, teamwork that actually matters, cavalry charging tanks, snipers crying in the distance, and you somewhere in the middle trying to survive the apocalypse.
Every gun has weight. Every explosion counts. Every push feels like a moment from a war movie.

And the operations mode?
Masterpiece. Peak content.
No Battlefield before or after managed to capture that feeling of two armies smashing into each other, inch by inch, flag by flag.
This mode alone carried the franchise on its back.

Verdict?
Battlefield 1 isn‚Äôt just the best Battlefield game ‚Äî it‚Äôs one of the best FPS games ever made, period.
Dice caught lightning in a bottle with this one and they never replicated it again.

10/10, still unmatched, still the king.
The GOAT of Battlefield.
Truly the best war-based game ever. Incredible sound design. A timeless classic, in my opinion.

There‚Äôs just something about this game that hits differently. I can‚Äôt explain it, but it feels so much smoother and more enjoyable than most modern shooters.
Despite the breathtaking advancements in game engines and the stunning visuals of today‚Äôs titles, I find that older games still offer a more satisfying experience.

I have played nearly exclusively back to basics (B2B), a gamemode with nothing but bolt action rifles, for the past 140 hours, all without HUD. The game is incredibly immersive, graphics that are so far ahead of it's time it is better looking than games that are 9 years older than it.
The game is still somehow populated and has no major issues, except maybe balance of some weapons.
The best way to experience it is clearly operations 
(also, B2B runs the same 4 maps exclusively on operations.)
Consider the rest of the review my experience with no HUD B2B.
Maps - There are 4, Monte grappa and Fao Fortress are incredibly stalematey. Both are sniper hell in vanilla, but now there are no vehicules and everyone is a sniper, so very attacker team dependent whether or not you will have fun.
The other two however, are a toe curling experience. I once had a perfect game on offense as a normal medic, with mk VI revolver, top score, 31 kills, all with no hud, on St. Quentin scar, the best B2B map, no questions asked, rarely stalemates, trench warfare is soooooo satisfying, atmosphere is absolutely incredible. Ballroom blitz first point might be the only section better than the first 2 points on st Quentin Scar, trench segments are incredible, I saw it stalemate exactly twice. 
B2B is best when you are forced into a tight space (aka trenches) Having a weapon that is not good in close combat in close combat drastically heightens the ttk, which makes fights feel more scrappy, longer and personal, instead of a who shoots first COD-fest. (I would give so much for a populated B2B Fort de Vaux server.) This brings us to gun (and melee) play.
DEAR GOD THE SHOVEL IS SO SATISFYING.
I have interacted with a person of the opposite sex at least once, getting a 9 killstreak with nothing but a shovel in a trench is comparable. I have 18 service stars (1800 kills) on the shovel, all the bolt actions have 12 in total, second highest is mk VI revolver with 14. The takedown animations make this game feel like a movie (especially with no hud). Hitting a revolver shot hipfire to shovel hit takedown combo is probably the second most satisfying way to kill people after takedowns. It just feels so scrappy. So desperate. The sounds your character makes when he sees a grenade are the best detail ever. Same with mud covering your gun as you fight.
HUD is very unneccesary if you can count to five (ten if you are british and are using the lee enfield) Checking if you can revive teammates with q (and hearing a voiceline) is an option, memorising enemy helmets / pressing q is also an option. Feels much more intense when you have to actually use your brain instead of shooting at the guys under red squares. Not knowing when your points are captured and having to actually look at flags on different points makes it so much more stressful in the best way possible.
Music fits great
TLDR: Shovel is toe-curlingly satisfying, go play B2B, turn off HUD, trenches are cool, I have a crippling fear of explosives, am going bald from the stress, SHOVEL!!!!!

Battlefield 1 is a first-person shooter developed by DICE and released in 2016. It shifts the series to World War I, offering a unique mix of historical authenticity and cinematic spectacle. The game stands out for its large-scale multiplayer battles, destructible environments, and immersive presentation that captures the chaos and brutality of early 20th-century warfare.

Multiplayer is the core experience. Up to 64 players fight across massive maps featuring trench warfare, open fields, and urban ruins. The class system‚ÄîAssault, Medic, Support, and Scout‚Äîreturns with distinct roles that encourage teamwork. Gunplay feels deliberate and weighty due to the era‚Äôs weapon design; rifles, bolt-actions, and early automatic weapons dominate, forcing players to adapt to slower pacing and closer engagements.

Vehicles play a crucial role. Tanks, biplanes, and cavalry offer mobility and power, while the game‚Äôs ‚ÄúBehemoth‚Äù units‚Äîmassive vehicles like airships, armored trains, and battleships‚Äîact as comeback mechanics that can shift the tide of battle. Each map is designed around these large machines, making every match unpredictable and cinematic.

Visually, Battlefield 1 is exceptional. The Frostbite engine delivers realistic lighting, weather, and terrain destruction that make the world feel alive. Explosions send debris flying, dynamic weather changes visibility, and each map‚Äîfrom the deserts of Sinai to the forests of Argonne‚Äîhas a strong atmosphere. The sound design is equally powerful, with thunderous artillery and haunting period music enhancing immersion.

The single-player campaign, War Stories, breaks from the linear formula of earlier entries. It tells multiple short, character-driven narratives across different fronts, each with unique gameplay styles and emotional tone. The stories focus on humanity and sacrifice rather than glorifying war, earning strong praise for presentation and tone.

Mechanically, the game balances historical accuracy with accessibility. Weapon customization is limited compared to modern settings, but progression systems, medals, and unlocks keep players engaged. The gameplay rewards positioning, coordination, and tactical awareness more than raw reflex.

In summary, Battlefield 1 revitalized the franchise by taking it back to a rarely explored era and executing it with scale and polish. Its mix of authenticity, spectacle, and teamwork made it one of the most memorable entries in the series. It remains a benchmark for immersive war shooters, blending artistry and design into one of DICE‚Äôs most accomplished works.

[h1]Review[/h1] 
I never was much interested in any battlefield, or giant pvp shooters in general. Sometimes WW1 or 2 shooters like Verdun or red orchestra and that‚Äôs about it. I decided to buy it mostly for the singleplayer campaign and after playing some multiplayer. It has its pros and cons but is a decent game with its issues

[u]Multiplayer[/u]
Generally, its battlefield 3 or 4 gameplay tacked on with a World War 1 skin. You have almost modern sniper scopes, tanks around every corner, people use big satchel charges like tanks are the most common thing to see. Planes are hard to fly and I never bothered to learn them but they can be really annoying killing machines as there are less options to counter them than ever. The presentation is something else. Its still battlefield with its arcade gameplay, but offers many aspects that make up for unique situations, like giant stationary turrets with their cool animation or bayonet charges. I did personally see not so many cheater like in battlefield V, but there probably are a few. My favourite is the operations mode than add a small storyline to the map you play, giving different objectives and dialogues in-between. Although some of the maps have absolute awful spots where stalemates will always be there due to their design probably being made by someone who loved metro in bf3. The Italian map is the worst. Aside that, there are lots of interesting weapons, but I don‚Äôt like that the focus is most of the time on automatic weapons. Those are completely accurate and make most single shot weapons obsolete. Switching weapons is another thing, you basically don‚Äôt have a modification system, rather every single weapon that is slightly different is a new one. So, you will be able to choose a scoped and non scoped version, both being the same weapon but cluttering at some point your selection menu. This forces you to remember weapons completely by their name. 

[u]Story[/u]
The singleplayer story follows multiple short stories in World War 1. Some have more interesting stories, some others not. Especially gameplay related. Some stories are rather short and straightforward; some are more open or offer more open levels which can be stealthed. Second feels rather tacked on, the only stealth option you have is throwing stones, silent takedown and sometimes a silenced weapon. Its okay, usually take down this, capture this flag or collect or destroy those 3 items at those 3 spots. Much closer what you do in the multiplayer than what the story offered in the previous games.  The stories also focus on different aspects of the gameplay like tank, flying, special unit suit, infantery, melee/stealth etc. It‚Äôs a good standalone aspect, that introduces naturally multiplayer aspects without having to practice them. Despite that some of them can feel boring, especially the desert sections and some of the flying and most of the tank stuff.

[u]Sound[/u]
Sound design is something that I think is the best portion of the game. Graphics aside, which can age over time, a well-made sound palette and songs can make a game forever feel original and good. Voice acting in many different native languages, lots of weapon sounds with echo plus a few good tracks added during gameplay without being overbearing.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Battlefield one chooses a more stylized graphic that looks almost cartoonish. I guess its to not make the game feel overly uncanny, as some of the cutscenes are so well made it almost looks realistic then it doesn‚Äôt. Adding some more colours making it look like a bit stylized keeps the edge off of making it hyper realistic without breaking immersion. Otherwise it mostly looks good, aside animations, especially death can look silly.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
All in all, I think its the most fun and unique battlefield game. Although the World War one setting feels more or less like a skin and gameplay is the same as it ever was, with some adjustments. The singleplayer was a breath of fresh air and the presentation of the multiplayer matches better than it ever was.  Just don‚Äôt expect anything but an arcade multiplayer shooter with a world war 1 skin.
